Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Bridging the Cyber and Water Worlds: Cyber-Aquatic Systems for Undergraduate Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The last decade has seen a research wave in terrestrial sensor networks, in which the embedded networked sensing technologies have revolutionized the way for human beings to understand and interact with the physical world on the land. This decade will witness a revolution for the water world: transformative cyber-aquatic technologies will enable us to densely deploy static and mobile systems in an underwater environment, significantly enhancing the spatial and temporal dimensions of our monitoring and exploration capabilities. The Underwater Sensor Network (UWSN) Lab at the University of Connecticut (UConn) recently launched an initiative on Cyber-Aquatic Systems (CAS). Part of the CAS initiative will be an REU site offering undergraduate students to participate in the cutting-edge technologies of cyber-aquatic systems and encouraging them to pursue academic careers and professionals by sparking interests through exciting research projects. A major goal of this interdisciplinary REU site project is to introduce the cutting-edge research and technologies in cyber-aquatic systems to undergraduate students in the early stages of their careers to spark their interests.

This REU work, as part of a collaborative action with REU site 1156837, will recruit a diverse group of undergraduate students to engage in research that will broaden their interest in academic careers and professions and help develop a globally competitive engineering workforce equipped with innovative cyber-aquatic technologies. Through integrated research, education and outreach programs, this REU site will better prepare these undergraduate participants for future careers in academia or industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The last decade has seen a research wave in terrestrial sensor networks, in which the embedded networked sensing technologies have revolutionized the way for human being to understand and interact with the physical world on the land. This decade will witness a revolution for the water world: transformative cyber-aquatic technologies will enable densely deployed static and mobile systems in an underwater environment, significantly enhancing the spatial and temporal dimensions of our monitoring and exploration capabilities. The vision of a cyber-acoustic system (CAS) is to create transformative technologies to realize the true ubiquity and high confidence for the observation and exploration systems in the water world. These new technologies bridging the cyber and aquatic worlds will transform the ways in observing and understanding the sparsely sampled oceans, estuaries, lakes and rivers.

Allied and integrated with the research objectives of cyber-acoustic systems, this project provided a research-experience-for-undergraduate (REU) site offering undergraduate students to participate the CAS initiative. A major goal of this interdisciplinary REU site project is to introduce the cutting-edge research and technologies in cyber-aquatic systems to undergraduate students in the early stages of their careers to spark their interests.

This REU site has been run for three years, and it has supported a total of nineteen (19) participants: eight in summer 2012, six in summer 2013, and five in summer 2014. These students are from multiple disciplines, including computer science, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, and civil engineering.

Through integrated research, education and outreach programs, this REU site aims to better prepare undergraduate students for their future careers (in academia or industry) and attract underrepresented groups (including women and minorities) and students from non-research universities to the STEM field. Over the three years in this program, 47% of our students were female, 26% percent were underrepresented minorities (URM). Excluding the overlap, female and URM students combined are 68% of the total students.

Students’ participation in the REU summer internship impacted their plans to pursue further education in computing research and engineering, as well as their interests in working in research laboratories. Out of fourteen students in 2012 and 2013, twelve have graduated from college, six of them are currently in graduate school (50%). The REU students have contributed significantly towards research, which lead to one journal paper and 10 conference papers involving REU students.

REU participants also disseminated their research to a broader community. In summer 2013, REU students participated in a planning workshop on the Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (I/U/CRC) on Smart Ocean Technology, describing their research to over 60 participants. In summer 2014, REU students helped to host visits of 30 high school students and about twenty high school teachers.
